Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploratory Research on Seismic Liquefaction of Sand at Low and High Confining Pressures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Liquefaction of water-saturated sand soils due to earthquake shaking has caused billions of dollars of damage in ports, bridges, highways, buried pipelines, foundations of buildings, and earth dams. Liquefaction is a complex phenomenon which is poorly understood, and practical liquefaction evaluation in engineering projects is done using empirical charts calibrated by observed performance in past earthquakes. While conservative, this procedure works well in most cases in which the liquefiable sand layer is under a vertical effective confining pressure of the order of 1 atmosphere. However, the charts cannot be directly extrapolated to much higher pressures, like those existing under a tall earth dam, where the pressure may reach 8 or 10 atmospheres. Laboratory testing has shown that using the charts directly would be dangerously unconservative, and that the liquefaction resistance predicted by the charts should be reduced by as much as 60 percent at those high pressures. The exact value of the reduction has significant economic implications and is currently a subject of controversy among experts. Part of the problem is the empirical nature of the research being conducted to settle the issue. In the last few years, the PIs have developed a fresh and more rational approach, which shows great promise. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will explore the application of this more rational approach through a small series of innovative cyclic loading and centrifuge laboratory tests on one loose sand, finding the exact law of reduction of liquefaction resistance at high pressure for that loose sand, and developing a template for further research for other loose and dense sands as well as for the range of circumstances found in engineering practice.

Current seismic liquefaction triggering evaluation of saturated sand layers uses empirical charts based on the Simplified Procedure and calibrated for an effective vertical overburden pressure of about 1 atmosphere. In projects like tall earth dams, the vertical pressure may reach 8-10 atmospheres. Cyclic stress-controlled laboratory testing suggests that the Cyclic Resistance Ratio, CRR, from the liquefaction charts must be decreased. The reduction is measured by the factor K-sigma. Various researchers have proposed very different values of K-sigma between 0.45 and 0.85 at a vertical pressure of 8 atmospheres. This exploratory research adopts a different, cyclic strain approach based on the field-measured shear wave velocity, to provide a more rational framework and decrease the uncertainty in K-sigma. A preliminary experimental determination will be conducted of the variation with pressure of the cyclic shear strain needed to trigger liquefaction, as well as of CRR, for pressures between 1 atmosphere and 8 atmospheres, using a loose sand and a small number of strain-controlled cyclic triaxial tests and centrifuge model tests.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Liquefaction of water-saturated sand soils due to earthquake shaking has caused billions of dollars of damage in ports, bridges, highways, buried pipelines, foundations of buildings, and earth dams. Liquefaction is a complex phenomenon which is poorly understood, and practical liquefaction evaluation in engineering projects is done using empirical field charts that provide the liquefaction resistance of the soil, calibrated by observed performance in past earthquakes. While conservative, this procedure works well in most cases in which the liquefiable sand layer is under a vertical effective overburden pressure of the order of 1 atm. However, the charts cannot be directly extrapolated to much higher pressures, like for example those existing under a tall earth dam subjected to earthquakes, where the pressure may reach 6 or 8 atm. Most laboratory testing prior to this project suggested that using the charts directly would be unconservative, and that the liquefaction resistance predicted by the charts should be reduced by as much as 50-60% at those high pressures. The need for this reduction and its exact value has significant economic implications and is currently a subject of controversy between the experts. Part of the problem is the empirical nature of the cyclic stress-controlled tests conducted to settle the issue, where unrealistically large strains develop compared to those needed to trigger liquefaction in the field.

 In the last few years, the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI) research team developed a novel and more rational approach to the problem, which was used very successfully in this EAGER project. The approach combines small-sample cyclic strain-controlled tests on the water-saturated sand at low and high confining pressures, with centrifuge model shaking tests on the same saturated sand, also at low and high confining pressures. The results are then combined to extract the liquefaction resistance of the soil at low and high pressures, determining the possible need and amount of liquefaction strength change due to the high pressure effect.

In this EAGER project, ten cyclic triaxial strain-controlled, small-sample tests and two centrifuge model tests were conducted, evaluating the liquefaction resistance of a 4.5 m thick saturated Ottawa sand layer, at pressures of 1 and 6 atm. The cyclic triaxial and other small-sample tests were conducted at the laboratory of the firm Geocomp in Acton, MA, while the centrifuge model experiments were conducted at the geotechnical centrifuge center of RPI, Troy, NY. Analysis of the results show a great degree of consistency between the two sets of tests, indicating that the liquefaction resistance of the Ottawa sand at 1 atm should be increased by 0-20% at 6 atm, and not decreased by 20-50% as currently recommended in the literature.  Expansion of the research using this approach for a range of high pressures, different sands and a variety of typical conditions existing in the field, is recommended in order to settle the issue of liquefaction resistance of soils at high pressures. If the results of this EAGER project on one sand are confirmed, large potential savings could be achieved in a number of civil infrastructure projects.
